children.title: earth, the
children.comment: Created and sustained by God, the world is both his possession and the dwelling-place of his creatures. As such, it should bring him glory, and will one day be judged by him.

cschildren.title: God created the earth from nothing
The earth belongs to God
God controls and sustains the earth
God's character seen on earth
The earth should resound to God's glory and praise
The earth is the habitation of human beings and the animals
God judges the earth
God will destroy the earth one day
God will create a new earth

children.title: land
children.comment: Areas of territory, the possession of which was regarded as a sign of security and prosperity. The land of Israel was regarded as the land promised by God to his people and a sign of his covenant faithfulness.

children.title: land, as a divine gift
children.comment: God's gift of the land of Israel is fundamental to the covenant promises made to Abraham and his descendants.

children.title: Land as part of God's creation
The boundaries of the promised land
God's promise and its gradual fulfilment
The promise made to the patriarchs

seealsos.comment: The patriarchs maintained only a very small part of the land.  But Genesis closes with the prospect of much more.

children.title: The promise confirmed during the wilderness wanderings
Entry delayed because of unbelief and rebellion
Criticial importance of obedience in the promised land

primaryrefs.comment: Moses, at the end of his life, urges all the Israelites always to remember the LORD and his commands; enjoyment of the land is dependent upon the people's obedience.
The theme of the book of Joshua is the land: chapters 1-12 its invasion and conquest, chapters 13-21 its division among the Israelite tribes.

children.title: Conflict with the Philistines over the land

primaryrefs.comment: Philistine aggression had imperilled the prospect of a full possession of the land until David overpowered them.

children.title: The land at rest and prosperous
The exile and subsequent return to the land
land, as a divine responsibility
children.comment: Israel's land is a gift from God, though ultimately it remains under divine ownership. Life in the land is therefore characterised by both privilege and responsibility.

children.title: The land is a gift from God
Eleven full tribes share the inheritance
Inherited land east of Jordan allotted by Moses
Inherited land west of Jordan allotted by Joshua and others
Levi receives no inheritance of land
Israelite households to hold their inheritance in perpetuity
The land remains under divine ownership
Responsibility to God for the land

primaryrefs.comment: The tithe of the land's produce given to the LORD, is a kind of rent, a way of acknowledging his ownership.

children.title: Responsibility to fellow Israelites in the land
Individual property rights to be respected
Violation of these rights severely condemned
Responsibility to the poor in the land

seealsos.comment: Debts probably include the labour of a debtor's dependants, working to pay off his debt.

children.title: The land reflects God's blessing and curse
land, spiritual aspects of
children.comment: Scripture presents land in a spiritual perspective. The whole earth, once perfect but now contaminated by the fall, will one day be renewed. There will be a new heaven and earth where life is abundant and God's presence is experienced for ever.

children.title: Paradise lost: expulsion from the garden
The promised land: an echo of Eden

astronomy
children.comment: The study of the stars and planets, with a view to understanding their movements and their use in fixing the time of significant events.

Divine wisdom permeates the whole creation

credited to Jesus Christ

children.title: It demonstrates the humility of the human race

Babylon
children.comment: In OT times, the commercial, religious and political capital of Babylonia, which was the dominant power in the Near East in the sixth century B.C. In the NT, ``Babylon'' signifies the world and its forces in opposition to God. It is often contrasted with ``the new Jerusalem'', in which God will finally reign supreme.

cschildren.title: The founding of Babylon

primaryrefs.comment: Shinar was an alternative name for Babylon.

cschildren.title: Biblical events prior to the exile in Babylon

children.title: Inhabitants of Babylon exiled to Samaria

secondaryrefs.comment: Hezekiah's reception of the envoys was designed to lead to a coalition against Assyria, but in the end it brought about the very opposite of what he had hoped for.

children.title: Manasseh, king of Judah, exiled to Babylon
Jehoiakim, king of Judah, becomes a vassal of Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon
Nebuchadnezzar conquers Jerusalem and deports the population

children.title: The people of Judah exiled in Babylon

Babylon used figuratively

seealsos.comment: Babylon is traditionally interpreted as Rome, but may also mean Mesopotamian Babylon, Egyptian Babylon, or Jerusalem.

children.title: Of the world opposed to God
cave
children.comment: A natural cavity in a rock face, often used as a place of refuge.

cschildren.title: Caves as places of refuge

a place of refuge in the face of divine judgment
a place of refuge for those being persecuted for their faith

children.title: cistern
children.comment: A reservoir for storing water collected from rainfall or from a spring. When empty, it was used for a variety of purposes. The word is also employed in a figurative sense.

cschildren.title: Cisterns were used to collect water

Cisterns used as symbols

children.title: deep, the
children.comment: Unfathomed waters, sometimes seen as existing under the earth, held back by God's power. The term is also used of deep seas, and in metaphorical contexts.

cschildren.title: Unfathomed waters
Deep seas
The deep used metaphorically of a desperate situation

children.title: fountain
children.comment: A source of natural spring water. Figuratively, it symbolises a place of cleansing, tears or sexual fulfilment. Significantly, God is pictured as a fountain of life.

cschildren.title: The fountain as a source of spring water
Figurative use of fountains

children.title: garden
children.comment: A piece of land where flowers, fruit and vegetables may be grown. The Garden of Eden was the garden entrusted to the care of Adam and Eve.

children.title: garden, natural
children.comment: A place of leisure for growing flowers, fruit and vegetables.

children.title: Jesus Christ betrayed in a garden
Jesus Christ buried in a garden tomb
Garden of Eden, the
children.comment: The garden created by God and entrusted to the care of Adam and Eve.

seealsos.comment: Ancient Egypt is likened to Eden

children.title: The place of fellowship with God
Where God made Eve and gave her to Adam
Where Adam and Eve lived in innocence
Where God abundantly provided for Adam and Eve

secondaryrefs.comment: The trees of Eden are important.  They are both the evidence of God's love and one is the focus of Adam's test.

children.title: The paradise that humanity has lost
Where Adam and Eve disobeyed God
Where humanity came under God's curse
The place from which Adam and Eve were banished
Where God first promised Satan's destruction
Where God first provided a covering for sinners

primaryrefs.comment: The word ``paradise'' (which means ``park'' or ``walled garden'') clearly refers back to the idea of Eden.

seealsos.comment: the former glory of the king of Tyre likened to that of Adam in the Garden of Eden

children.comment: A place of leisure for growing flowers, fruit and vegetables.

children.title: islands
children.comment: Used of the islands and coastlands of the eastern Mediterranean and, especially by Isaiah, as a more general term indicating distant nations that are called upon to respond to God. Several specific islands are mentioned in the NT.

cschildren.title: The islands and coastlands of the Mediterranean
Islands as a symbol of human insignificance before God
Islands as a symbol of distant nations

children.title: Nations who do not know God
Nations who are not beyond God's law and judgment
Nations called to respond to God

cschildren.title: Islands mentioned in the NT

secondaryrefs.comment: Syracuse was the leading city of Sicily.

cschildren.title: The moon created by God
The moon listed among the heavenly bodies
The moon as a basis for the calendar

children.title: Months marked by the new moon

cschildren.title: The moon as a symbol of permanence
Idolatrous worship of the moon
Signs in the moon indicating divine intervention
The moon thought to affect the mind

secondaryrefs.comment: The moon is indicated as a source of danger
The Greek expression translated ``having seizures'' originally meant ``moonstruck''.

children.title: mountains
children.comment: These natural features of Palestine are often used as poetic symbols when describing God or his dealings with his people. Specific mountains are remembered because of their association with important events in the history of Israel. Some of the key events in the life and ministry of Jesus Christ take place on mountain sites.

cschildren.title: Mountains and the character of God

children.title: Mountains and the steadfastness of God
Mountains tremble at God's awesome presence

primaryrefs.comment: The violent physical response to the presence of the holy God evokes a sense of his might and majesty.

children.title: Mountains cannot stand before the anger of God

cschildren.title: Mountains as places of encounter with God
Specific mountains as the sites of important events in Israel's history

children.title: The mountains of Abarim: site of Israel's camp
Mount Ararat: resting place of Noah's ark
Mount Carmel: scene of Elijah's defeat of the prophets of Baal
Mount Ebal: site of cursing; Mount Gerizim: site of blessing
Mount Gilboa: place of Saul's suicide
Mount Hermon: a boundary of Israel
Mount Hor: place of Aaron's death
Mount Moriah: testing place of Abraham
Mount Moriah: site of Solomon's temple
Mount Nebo: place of Moses' death
Mount Sinai: God gives Moses the law
Mount Tabor: scene of Sisera's defeat

cschildren.title: Mountains as the sites of significant events in the NT

children.title: On the Mount of Temptation the devil offers Jesus Christ the kingdoms of the world
In the Sermon on the Mount Jesus Christ teaches about life in the kingdom of God
On the Mount of Transfiguration Jesus Christ's glory is revealed
On the Mount of Olives Jesus Christ teaches about the destruction of the temple and the last things

cschildren.title: A hole in the ground
A pit used as a trap
A pit as a symbol of distress or grief
The pit as a term for the grave
The pit as a symbol of judgment

children.title: rivers and streams
children.comment: The term river is used to refer to all kinds of watercourses, including wadis (dried-up desert river beds) and permanent rivers. It is also used symbolically to refer to things which threaten or overwhelm people and nations, such as invading nations, the peace of God and the Holy Spirit.

cschildren.title: Different kinds of rivers and streams

primaryrefs.comment: Wadis were dry river beds in summer but became raging torrents in the rainy season.

seealsos.comment: The Jabbok was a wadi, here in full flow
Although called a river here, the Kebar was a canal of the Euphrates.

cschildren.title: Some significant rivers and streams in Scripture

children.title: River Arnon
children.precomment: The Arnon flowed through Moab to the mid point of the Dead Sea:

secondaryrefs.comment: The Abana flowed through the city of Damascus and the Pharpar just to the south of it.

children.title: River Euphrates
children.precomment: The Euphrates flowed through Mesopotamia for some 1,700 miles (2,700 km) from its source in eastern Turkey to the Persian Gulf:

secondaryrefs.comment: The Habor was a tributary of the Euphrates.

children.title: River Jabbok
children.precomment: The Jabbok flowed westward through Gilead into the Jordan about 20 miles (32 km) north of the Dead Sea:

children.title: River Jordan
children.precomment: The Jordan flowed from the slopes of Mount Hermon through Lake Huleh and the Sea of Galilee, and on into the Dead Sea, providing a fertile basin on either side of the river:

children.title: River Kebar
children.precomment: The Kebar was a canal of the Euphrates in Babylon where the exiles gathered to pray:

secondaryrefs.comment: The exact location of this wadi is uncertain, but it ran from the east into the Jordan or one of its tributaries.

children.title: River Kishon
children.precomment: The Kishon flowed north-west across the Plain of Megiddo and could quickly flood as a result of storms:

children.title: River Nile
children.precomment: The Nile flowed north some 3,500 miles (5,600 km) from Lake Victoria to the Mediterranean, providing a natural irrigation system in the desert through its annual floodings:

children.title: River Tigris
children.precomment: The Tigris flowed from the Armenian mountains through Mesopotamia to join the Euphrates some 40 miles (65 km) north of the Persian Gulf:

cschildren.title: The crossing of rivers and streams

children.title: Rivers crossed by miraculous intervention from God

cschildren.title: Human uses of rivers and streams

primaryrefs.comment: The reference may be to a machine operated by foot, or to the foot breaking through the mud walls of the irrigation channel to let the water flow into the fields.

cschildren.title: God as sovereign Creator is ruler and judge over all rivers and streams
The symbolic use of rivers and streams

children.title: A symbol of God's judgment on his enemies

primaryrefs.comment: ``Baal Perazim'' means ``the lord who breaks out''. The picture is of a river bursting its banks.

children.title: A symbol of God's sustaining power
A symbol of God's provision and blessing
A symbol of renewal and life
A symbol of the Holy Spirit
Rome
children.comment: The city state at the heart of the great world empire of NT times, pictured in the book of Revelation as the embodiment of corrupt earthly power. A large church had been established in Rome long before Paul arrived there, towards the end of his life and his mission. His letter to the believers in Rome includes a comprehensive explanation of the gospel.

cschildren.title: Rome and the mission of Paul

children.title: Jesus Christ confirms that Paul will preach the gospel in Rome
Paul is sent for trial in Rome

cschildren.title: The church in Rome existed long before Paul's arrival

seealsos.comment: Although Paul had never been to Rome, he seemed to be personally acquainted with 26 people associated with the church there, so its overall size was probably quite considerable.

cschildren.title: Paul's letter to the church in Rome presents the whole gospel

primaryrefs.comment: The gospel is God's offer of salvation to all.

children.title: Sin and the universal need for salvation
God's ``rescue'' through Jesus Christ available to all
Peace with God through believing in Jesus Christ

cschildren.title: Rome is pictured as the embodiment of corrupt earthly power

primaryrefs.comment: Verse 9 clearly identifies the city as Rome, widely known then as the city built on seven hills.

seealsos.comment: Babylon was the great godless city of the OT and here is taken by most commentators to depict Rome, which in turn represents corrupt worldly power in general. However, some believe that only a general reference to the world system is in mind, and others that a literal reference to the actual city of Babylon is intended

cschildren.title: The sea created and controlled by God
Creatures of the sea

children.title: Sea monsters sometimes represented spiritual forces

cschildren.title: The sea represented hidden depths
Named seas

primaryrefs.comment: In NT times referring to an area extending south of the present Adriatic Sea.

cschildren.title: The Sea before the temple
The sea before the throne
Metaphorical references to the sea
No more sea

children.title: Sinai, Mount
children.comment: The mountain in the Sinai peninsula (probably present-day Jebel Musa), also called Horeb in the OT, where God made a covenant with Israel, establishing them as his people and giving them his laws. In the NT Sinai is seen as symbolising the old covenant.

cschildren.title: Mount Sinai and the call of Moses

primaryrefs.comment: Most scholars agree that the names Horeb and Sinai are used interchangeably of the same mountain, although some see them as referring to separate peaks within the same range.

cschildren.title: God reveals himself to Israel at Mount Sinai

children.title: The people of Israel arrive at Mount Sinai three months after leaving Egypt
God promises to make Israel his people
God calls for holiness among his people

cschildren.title: God gives his laws to Israel on Mount Sinai

children.title: God gives Israel the Ten Commandments
Israel responds with fear to God's revelation
God gives Israel the Book of the Covenant

secondaryrefs.comment: These laws, largely an expansion and exposition of the Ten Commandments, are called ``the Book of the Covenant'' in Ex 24:7.

cschildren.title: God establishes the covenant with Israel on Mount Sinai

children.title: Moses performs the ceremony establishing the covenant
Moses and other leaders ascend Mount Sinai to seal the covenant with a meal before God
Moses ascends Mount Sinai further to receive the stone tablets and the requirements of covenant worship

primaryrefs.comment: During Moses' 40 days on Mount Sinai, God revealed to him the requirements of covenant worship, as outlined in Ex 25:1-31:18.

cschildren.title: Moses descends Mount Sinai and discovers Israel's idolatry
God commands Israel to move on from Mount Sinai
God calls Moses up Mount Sinai again

children.title: Moses is commanded to prepare new stone tablets
God reveals his nature and name to Moses
God renews his covenant with Israel
Moses descends Mount Sinai, his face radiant

cschildren.title: The people of Israel prepare to move on from Mount Sinai

children.title: God commands Moses to take a census of Israel in the Desert of Sinai
The Israelites celebrate the Passover at Mount Sinai

secondaryrefs.comment: The Israelites had been at Mount Sinai for almost a year (see also Ex 19:1)

cschildren.title: Later generations look back to God's revelation on Mount Sinai

primaryrefs.comment: Ascribing the title ``the One of Sinai'' to God, Deborah acknowledges the great importance of his revelation at Mount Sinai.

seealsos.comment: Elijah's return to Horeb, the mountain of God, shows his need to hear God clearly again

cschildren.title: Mount Sinai seen by NT writers as a symbol of the old covenant

secondaryrefs.comment: Hagar, Mount Sinai and the present city of Jerusalem stand for the old covenant and bondage to the law, while Sarah and the new heavenly Jerusalem stand for the new covenant and living by faith

seealsos.comment: a promise repeated many times in the OT

The sky associated with rain and hail
The sky associated with unusual phenomena
The sky used figuratively

children.title: Sodom and Gomorrah
children.comment: Two neighbouring cities, probably located at the eastern or south-eastern end of the Dead Sea, noted for their sinfulness. God's response in wrath and judgment serves as a warning to subsequent generations.

Sodom became Lot's home

The story of Sodom and Gomorrah becomes a picture of human sinfulness and divine judgment

children.title: spring of water
children.comment: Springs of water were important to the life of Israel, providing fresh water for the people. Both God and the gospel are often compared to springs of living water, on account of their life-bringing and refreshing qualities.

cschildren.title: The symbolic importance of springs of water to Israel

children.title: Living water as a sign of hope and prosperity
Living water as a source of fertility
Living water as a sign of God's presence and power

cschildren.title: God as a spring of water

secondaryrefs.comment: the tongue compared to a spring
a dry spring as a symbol of sterility

children.title: stars
children.comment: Heavenly luminaries other than the sun and moon, often worshipped as gods by pagan nations. Scripture stresses that the stars were created by God, and are subject to him. Stars are often treated as symbols of the generosity of God, and his faithfulness to his promises.

cschildren.title: The relationship between God and the stars

children.title: The stars demonstrate the power of their maker

cschildren.title: Worship of the stars
Reading the stars
Signs in the stars
The star of Bethlehem
The stars illustrating God's promise to Abraham
Metaphorical references to the stars

children.title: sun
children.comment: Created as a source of light and heat and an indicator of time and direction. The sun is also used as a metaphor for the splendour and light of God himself and the righteousness of his people.

cschildren.title: Natural functions of the sun

children.title: The scorching heat causing discomfort and harm

cschildren.title: Worship of the sun

children.title: The setting sun signifying a premature end

cschildren.title: Miracles and signs concerning the sun

children.title: universe
children.comment: All existing things, including the earth and its creatures and all the heavenly bodies. The universe was made by God and is sustained by Jesus Christ.

Jesus Christ, the one through whom the universe was made, now sustains all things

water
children.comment: The colourless, odourless liquid that is essential for sustenance of life in human beings and animals. God is described as the spring of living water, being the source of life and salvation to those who come to him.

seealsos.comment: God provides water for Hagar and Ishmael
Elijah asks the widow at Zarephath for a drink of water

Abundance of water as a sign of blessing
Baptism in water

Metaphorical references to water

children.title: wells
children.comment: Artificial openings to tap underground water supplies. They were very important for life in a settled urban society and this is reflected in their symbolical use in Scripture.

cschildren.title: The importance of wells in urban life
Women drew water for domestic use
Livestock were watered at wells

Wells as landmarks

primaryrefs.comment: Verse 14 refers to this spring as a well.

seealsos.comment: ``Beersheba'' means either ``well of seven'' or ``well of the oath''

children.title: Associated with God and his goodness
In warnings against and judgment of sin
